name: Turla
descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) is a cyber espionage threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB).  They have compromised victims in over 50 countries since at least 2004, spanning a range of industries including government, embassies, military, education, research and pharmaceutical companies. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) is known for conducting watering hole and spearphishing campaigns, and leveraging in-house tools and malware, such as [Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022).(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)(Citation: CrowdStrike VENOMOUS BEAR)(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)

subtechniques.name: Create Process with Token
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors can impersonate or steal process tokens before executing commands.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

subtechniques.name: Local Account
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used net user to enumerate local accounts on the system.(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)(Citation: ESET Crutch December 2020)

subtechniques.name: Domain Account
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used net user /domain to enumerate domain accounts.(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)

subtechniques.name: Web Services
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has created web accounts including Dropbox and GitHub for C2 and document exfiltration.(Citation: ESET Crutch December 2020)

subtechniques.name: Web Protocols
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used HTTP and HTTPS for C2 communications.(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito May 2018)

subtechniques.name: Mail Protocols
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used multiple backdoors which communicate with a C2 server via email attachments.(Citation: Crowdstrike GTR2020 Mar 2020)

subtechniques.name: Archive via Utility
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has encrypted files stolen from connected USB drives into a RAR file before exfiltration.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)

subtechniques.name: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder
subtechniques.descr: A [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) Javascript backdoor added a local_update_check value under the Registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to establish persistence. Additionally, a [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) custom executable containing Metasploit shellcode is saved to the Startup folder to gain persistence.(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito May 2018)(Citation: ESET Turla Lunar toolset May 2024)

subtechniques.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) established persistence by adding a Shell value under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon.(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)

technique_table_data.name: Brute Force
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) may attempt to connect to systems within a victim's network using net use commands and a predefined list or collection of passwords.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

subtechniques.name: PowerShell
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used PowerShell to execute commands/scripts, in some cases via a custom executable or code from [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363)'s PSInject.(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito May 2018)(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019) [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has also used PowerShell scripts to load and execute malware in memory.

subtechniques.name: Windows Command Shell
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have used cmd.exe to execute commands.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)

subtechniques.name: Visual Basic
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used VBS scripts throughout its operations.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)

subtechniques.name: Python
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used IronPython scripts as part of the [IronNetInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0581) toolchain to drop payloads.(Citation: Unit 42 IronNetInjector February 2021 )

subtechniques.name: JavaScript
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used various JavaScript-based backdoors.(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)

subtechniques.name: Virtual Private Server
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used the VPS infrastructure of compromised Iranian threat actors.(Citation: NSA NCSC Turla OilRig)

subtechniques.name: Server
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used compromised servers as infrastructure.(Citation: Recorded Future Turla Infra 2020)(Citation: Accenture HyperStack October 2020)(Citation: Talos TinyTurla September 2021)

subtechniques.name: Web Services
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has frequently used compromised WordPress sites for C2 infrastructure.(Citation: Recorded Future Turla Infra 2020)

subtechniques.name: Windows Credential Manager
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has gathered credentials from the Windows Credential Manager tool.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)

technique_table_data.name: Data from Information Repositories
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used a custom .NET tool to collect documents from an organization's internal central database.(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)

technique_table_data.name: Data from Local System
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors can upload files from victim machines.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

technique_table_data.name: Data from Removable Media
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors can collect files from USB thumb drives.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)

technique_table_data.name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used a custom decryption routine, which pulls key and salt values from other artifacts such as a WMI filter or [PowerShell Profile](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1546/013), to decode encrypted PowerShell payloads.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

subtechniques.name: Malware
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has developed its own unique malware for use in operations.(Citation: Recorded Future Turla Infra 2020)

technique_table_data.name: Drive-by Compromise
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has infected victims using watering holes.(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)(Citation: Secureworks IRON HUNTER Profile)

subtechniques.name: Windows Management Instrumentation Event Subscription
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used WMI event filters and consumers to establish persistence.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

subtechniques.name: PowerShell Profile
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used PowerShell profiles to maintain persistence on an infected machine.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

subtechniques.name: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used WebDAV to upload stolen USB files to a cloud drive.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019) [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has also exfiltrated stolen files to OneDrive and 4shared.(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)

technique_table_data.name: Exploitation for Privilege Escalation
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has exploited vulnerabilities in the VBoxDrv.sys driver to obtain kernel mode privileges.(Citation: Unit42 AcidBox June 2020)

technique_table_data.name: File and Directory Discovery
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover files in specific locations on the hard disk %TEMP% directory, the current user's desktop, the Program Files directory, and Recent.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020) [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have also searched for files matching the lPH*.dll pattern.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

technique_table_data.name: Group Policy Discovery
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover Group Policy details using the gpresult command.(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)

subtechniques.name: File/Path Exclusions
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has placed [LunarWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1141) install files into directories that are excluded from scanning.(Citation: ESET Turla Lunar toolset May 2024)

subtechniques.name: Disable or Modify Tools
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used a AMSI bypass, which patches the in-memory amsi.dll, in PowerShell scripts to bypass Windows antimalware products.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

technique_table_data.name: Ingress Tool Transfer
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used shellcode to download Meterpreter after compromising a victim.(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito May 2018)

technique_table_data.name: Lateral Tool Transfer
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors can be used to transfer files to/from victim machines on the local network.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)

subtechniques.name: Match Legitimate Resource Name or Location
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has named components of [LunarWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1141) to mimic Zabbix agent logs.(Citation: ESET Turla Lunar toolset May 2024)

technique_table_data.name: Modify Registry
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has modified Registry values to store payloads.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)

technique_table_data.name: Native API
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) and its RPC backdoors have used APIs calls for various tasks related to subverting AMSI and accessing then executing commands through RPC and/or named pipes.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

subtechniques.name: Indicator Removal from Tools
subtechniques.descr: Based on comparison of [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) versions, [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) made an effort to obfuscate strings in the malware that could be used as IoCs, including the mutex name and named pipe.(Citation: ESET Gazer Aug 2017)

subtechniques.name: Command Obfuscation
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used encryption (including salted 3DES via [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194)'s Out-EncryptedScript.ps1), random variable names, and base64 encoding to obfuscate PowerShell commands and payloads.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

subtechniques.name: Fileless Storage
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used the Registry to store encrypted and encoded payloads.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)

subtechniques.name: Malware
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used malware obtained after compromising other threat actors, such as [OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049).(Citation: NSA NCSC Turla OilRig)(Citation: Recorded Future Turla Infra 2020)

subtechniques.name: Tool
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has obtained and customized publicly-available tools like [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)

technique_table_data.name: Password Policy Discovery
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used net accounts and net accounts /domain to acquire password policy information.(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)

technique_table_data.name: Peripheral Device Discovery
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used fsutil fsinfo drives to list connected drives.(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)

subtechniques.name: Local Groups
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used net localgroup and net localgroup Administrators to enumerate group information, including members of the local administrators group.(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)

subtechniques.name: Domain Groups
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used net group "Domain Admins" /domain to identify domain administrators.(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)

subtechniques.name: Spearphishing Link
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) attempted to trick targets into clicking on a link featuring a seemingly legitimate domain from Adobe.com to download their malware and gain initial access.(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)

technique_table_data.name: Process Discovery
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover running processes using the tasklist /v command.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla) [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have also enumerated processes associated with specific open ports or named pipes.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

technique_table_data.name: Process Injection

subtechniques.name: Dynamic-link Library Injection
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used Metasploit to perform reflective DLL injection in order to escalate privileges.(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito May 2018)(Citation: Github Rapid7 Meterpreter Elevate)

technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has also used [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194)'s Invoke-ReflectivePEInjection.ps1 to reflectively load a PowerShell payload into a random process on the victim system.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

technique_table_data.name: Proxy
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have included local UPnP RPC proxies.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

subtechniques.name: Internal Proxy
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has compromised internal network systems to act as a proxy to forward traffic to C2.(Citation: Talos TinyTurla September 2021)

technique_table_data.name: Query Registry
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover information in the Windows Registry with the reg query command.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla) [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has also retrieved PowerShell payloads hidden in Registry keys as well as checking keys associated with null session named pipes .(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

subtechniques.name: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) used net use commands to connect to lateral systems within a network.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

technique_table_data.name: Remote System Discovery
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover remote systems on a local network using the net view and net view /DOMAIN commands. [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has also used net group "Domain Computers" /domain, net group "Domain Controllers" /domain, and net group "Exchange Servers" /domain to enumerate domain computers, including the organization's DC and Exchange Server.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)

subtechniques.name: Security Software Discovery
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has obtained information on security software, including security logging information that may indicate whether their malware has been detected.(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)

subtechniques.name: Code Signing Policy Modification
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has modified variables in kernel memory to turn off Driver Signature Enforcement after exploiting vulnerabilities that obtained kernel mode privileges.(Citation: Unit42 AcidBox June 2020)(Citation: GitHub Turla Driver Loader)

technique_table_data.name: System Information Discovery
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover operating system configuration details using the systeminfo and set commands.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)

technique_table_data.name: System Network Configuration Discovery
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover network configuration details using the arp -a, nbtstat -n, net config, ipconfig /all, and route commands, as well as [NBTscan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0590).(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020) [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have also retrieved registered RPC interface information from process memory.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

subtechniques.name: Internet Connection Discovery
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used tracert to check internet connectivity.(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020)

technique_table_data.name: System Network Connections Discovery
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover active local network connections using the netstat -an, net use, net file, and net session commands.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: ESET ComRAT May 2020) [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have also enumerated the IPv4 TCP connection table via the GetTcpTable2 API call.(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)

technique_table_data.name: System Service Discovery
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover running services and associated processes using the tasklist /svc command.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

technique_table_data.name: System Time Discovery
technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover the system time by using the net time command.(Citation: Kaspersky Turla)

subtechniques.name: Malicious Link
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used spearphishing via a link to get users to download and run their malware.(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)

subtechniques.name: Local Accounts
subtechniques.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has abused local accounts that have the same password across the victim’s network.(Citation: ESET Crutch December 2020)

technique_table_data.name: Web Service

subtechniques.name: Bidirectional Communication
subtechniques.descr: A [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) JavaScript backdoor has used Google Apps Script as its C2 server.(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito May 2018)

technique_table_data.descr: [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used legitimate web services including Pastebin, Dropbox, and GitHub for C2 communications.(Citation: Accenture HyperStack October 2020)(Citation: ESET Crutch December 2020)

software_data.name: Carbon
software_data.descr: (Citation: ESET Carbon Mar 2017)(Citation: Secureworks IRON HUNTER Profile)

software_data.name: ComRAT
software_data.descr: (Citation: Symantec Waterbug)(Citation: Unit 42 IronNetInjector February 2021 )(Citation: Secureworks IRON HUNTER Profile)

software_data.name: Crutch
software_data.descr: (Citation: ESET Crutch December 2020)(Citation: Talos TinyTurla September 2021)

software_data.name: Empire
software_data.descr: (Citation: ESET Turla August 2018)(Citation: ESET Crutch December 2020)

techniques.name: Hijack Execution Flow
techniques.sub_name: Path Interception by Search Order Hijacking

techniques.name: Hijack Execution Flow
techniques.sub_name: Path Interception by PATH Environment Variable

software_data.name: Epic
software_data.descr: (Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: Secureworks IRON HUNTER Profile)

software_data.name: Kazuar
software_data.descr: (Citation: Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017)(Citation: Talos TinyTurla September 2021)

software_data.name: LightNeuron
software_data.descr: (Citation: ESET LightNeuron May 2019)(Citation: Secureworks IRON HUNTER Profile)

techniques.name: Masquerading
techniques.sub_name: Match Legitimate Resource Name or Location

software_data.name: Mimikatz
software_data.descr: (Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito May 2018)(Citation: Symantec Waterbug Jun 2019)

software_data.name: Mosquito
software_data.descr: (Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito Jan 2018)(Citation: ESET Turla Mosquito May 2018)(Citation: Secureworks IRON HUNTER Profile)

techniques.name: File and Directory Permissions Modification
techniques.sub_name: Linux and Mac File and Directory Permissions Modification

techniques.name: Masquerading
techniques.sub_name: Match Legitimate Resource Name or Location

software_data.name: Systeminfo
software_data.descr: (Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: ESET Turla Lunar toolset May 2024)

techniques.name: Masquerading
techniques.sub_name: Match Legitimate Resource Name or Location

software_data.name: Uroburos
software_data.descr: (Citation: Kaspersky Turla)(Citation: Joint Cybersecurity Advisory AA23-129A Snake Malware May 2023)

alias_descriptions.name: Waterbug
alias_descriptions.descr: Based similarity in TTPs and malware used, Turla and Waterbug appear to be the same group.(Citation: Symantec Waterbug)

alias_descriptions.name: WhiteBear
alias_descriptions.descr: WhiteBear is a designation used by Securelist to describe a cluster of activity that has overlaps with activity described by others as Turla, but appears to have a separate focus.(Citation: Securelist WhiteBear Aug 2017)(Citation: Talos TinyTurla September 2021)

alias_descriptions.name: Snake
alias_descriptions.descr: (Citation: CrowdStrike VENOMOUS BEAR)(Citation: ESET Turla PowerShell May 2019)(Citation: Talos TinyTurla September 2021)

alias_descriptions.name: Venomous Bear
alias_descriptions.descr: (Citation: CrowdStrike VENOMOUS BEAR)(Citation: Talos TinyTurla September 2021)

Talos TinyTurla September 2021.description: Cisco Talos. (2021, September 21). TinyTurla - Turla deploys new malware to keep a secret backdoor on victim machines. Retrieved December 2, 2021.

ESET Crutch December 2020.description: Faou, M. (2020, December 2). Turla Crutch: Keeping the “back door” open. Retrieved December 4, 2020.

ESET Turla Mosquito May 2018.description: ESET Research. (2018, May 22). Turla Mosquito: A shift towards more generic tools. Retrieved July 3, 2018.

Unit42 AcidBox June 2020.description: Reichel, D. and Idrizovic, E. (2020, June 17). AcidBox: Rare Malware Repurposing Turla Group Exploit Targeted Russian Organizations. Retrieved March 16, 2021.

Crowdstrike GTR2020 Mar 2020.description: Crowdstrike. (2020, March 2). 2020 Global Threat Report. Retrieved December 11, 2020.

ESET Turla Lunar toolset May 2024.description: Jurčacko, F. (2024, May 15). To the Moon and back(doors): Lunar landing in diplomatic missions. Retrieved June 26, 2024.

Unit 42 IronNetInjector February 2021.description: Reichel, D. (2021, February 19). IronNetInjector: Turla’s New Malware Loading Tool. Retrieved February 24, 2021.

GitHub Turla Driver Loader.description: TDL Project. (2016, February 4). TDL (Turla Driver Loader). Retrieved April 22, 2021.

ESET Turla August 2018.description: ESET. (2018, August). Turla Outlook Backdoor: Analysis of an unusual Turla backdoor. Retrieved March 11, 2019.

Mandiant Suspected Turla Campaign Februa.description: Hawley, S. et al. (2023, February 2). Turla: A Galaxy of Opportunity. Retrieved May 15, 2023.

Unit 42 Kazuar May 2017.description: Levene, B, et al. (2017, May 03). Kazuar: Multiplatform Espionage Backdoor with API Access. Retrieved July 17, 2018.

ESET LightNeuron May 2019.description: Faou, M. (2019, May). Turla LightNeuron: One email away from remote code execution. Retrieved June 24, 2019.

ESET Carbon Mar 2017.description: ESET. (2017, March 30). Carbon Paper: Peering into Turla’s second stage backdoor. Retrieved November 7, 2018.
